questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of primary liver tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hepatocellular carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common type of primary liver tumor.
    • It arises from hepatocytes and is frequently associated with chronic liver diseases such as hepatitis B and C, as well as cirrhosis.
  • Metastatic tumors are the most common type of liver tumor overall (Option A).
    • The liver is a common site for metastasis from cancers such as colorectal, breast, and lung cancer.
  • Hepatoblastoma is the most common pediatric liver cancer but is much less common than HCC in adults. (Option C)
  • Hemangioma is the most common benign liver tumor and is usually asymptomatic, often discovered incidentally during imaging for other reasons. (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a history of chronic hepatitis B presents with abdominal discomfort and weight loss. Imaging studies reveal a primary liver tumor with multiple metastatic lesions. Considering the typical metastatic pattern of liver tumors, what is the most likely site of these metastases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lungs

Explanation:

Primary liver tumors, such as hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), typically metastasize to specific sites in a common order:

  1. Lungs: The lungs are the most common site for metastasis from HCC.
    • Pulmonary metastases often occur due to the extensive blood flow from the liver to the lungs.
  2. Lymph nodes: Regional lymph nodes are also frequently involved in metastasis from liver tumors.
  3. Bones: Metastasis to bones can occur and may present with symptoms such as bone pain or fractures.
  4. Brain: While less common, brain metastases can occur in advanced stages of liver cancer.
  5. Kidneys: Metastasis to the kidneys is not typical for primary liver tumors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is incidentally found to have a 5 cm hepatic lesion on an ultrasound performed for evaluation of vague abdominal discomfort. A contrast-enhanced MRI shows a lesion with peripheral nodular enhancement and centripetal filling in the delayed phase. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Observation with periodic imaging

Explanation:

 

  • A hepatic lesion was incidentally discovered on ultrasound, commonly associated with hepatic hemangiomas.
  • MRI reveals peripheral nodular enhancement with centripetal filling in the delayed phase, highly specific for hepatic hemangiomas.
  • Given these imaging features and the absence of symptoms or abnormal liver function, the diagnosis of a hepatic hemangioma is strongly supported.

 

Management

  • For small, asymptomatic hemangiomas, the standard management is observation with periodic imaging.
  • Surgical intervention is reserved for cases where the hemangioma is symptomatic, exceeds 10 cm, shows diagnostic uncertainty after imaging, ruptures, or leads to Kasabach-Merritt syndrome.
  • When surgery is indicated, the preferred approach is enucleation with arterial inflow control.

questions.text: During a routine abdominal ultrasound of a 35-year-old female, a liver lesion was noted. imaging with a CECT scan shows a central stellate scar within the lesion. The patient is on oral contraceptive pills. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Focal nodular hyperplasia

Explanation:

  • Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is the 2nd most common benign tumor of the liver.
  • It is typically asymptomatic and often discovered incidentally during imaging for other reasons.
  • It is more common in females and is associated with oral contraceptive pill use.

Diagnosis:

  • The investigation of choice for FNH is contrast-enhanced CT (CECT), which typically shows a characteristic central stellate scar due to the presence of a central feeding arteriole with multiple peripheral branches.
  • Angiography may show a spoke-wheel or cartwheel pattern due to abnormal vascularity.

 

A: arterial phase B: portal phase C: magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) D: pathological examination of the resected specimen.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with complaints of right upper quadrant abdominal pain for the past few weeks. She has a history of using oral contraceptive pills for the past 5 years. On examination, the physician palpates a slightly tender, smooth, and well-defined mass in the right upper quadrant. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C Hepatic adenoma

Explanation:

  • Hepatic adenoma is a benign proliferative disorder of hepatocytes. 
  • They are more common in females on OCPs.
  • They are characterized by poorly supported peripherally located blood vessels. This can lead to:
    • An increased risk of hemorrhage and necrosis
    • Abdominal pain
    • A high risk of tumor rupture (30-50%). In contrast, the risk of rupture in hepatocellular carcinoma is only 3-5%.
    • An increased risk of tumour rupture during pregnancy

questions.text: In which of the following conditions are these CECT findings seen?
questions.solution:
Answer: (D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • The above CECT image shows a central stellate scar.
  • This is because of the central feeding arteriole, which has multiple peripheral branches.
  • A central stellate scar is most commonly seen in Focal Nodular Hyperplasia.
  • But central stellate scar on CECT can also be seen in:
    • Fibrolamellar variant of Hepatocellular carcinoma
    • Serous cystadenoma of the pancreas
    • Renal oncocytoma

 

A: arterial phase B: portal phase C: magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) D: pathological examination of the resected specimen.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with persistent abdominal pain and unexplained weight loss He has a history of chronic hepatitis B infection and moderate alcohol consumption. Physical examination reveals mild jaundice and hepatomegaly. Which of the following risk factors is most strongly associated with developing hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hepatitis B infection

Explanation:

  • Worldwide, the most common risk factor for liver cancer is chronic (long-term) infection with hepatitis B virus (HBV) or hepatitis C virus (HCV).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic hepatitis C and cirrhosis presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and abdominal discomfort. On physical examination, you note mild ascites and hepatomegaly. The serum alpha-fetoprotein level is elevated. What is the investigation of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Triple phase CT

Explanation:

  • In a patient with known risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), such as chronic hepatitis C and cirrhosis, and elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein levels, the investigation of choice is Triple phase CT.
  • The preferred method for definitive diagnosis of HCC is a Triple Phase CT scan, which highlights arterial hypervascularization and venous washout.
  • A triple-phase CT scan has the following phases:
    • Arterial Phase - HCC shows hyperenhancement due to its arterial blood supply.
    • Portal Venous Phase - HCC may appear isodense or hypodense as it becomes less conspicuous compared to the surrounding liver tissue.
    • Delayed Phase - HCC exhibits washout, a characteristic feature - appearing hypodense relative to the liver parenchyma.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a history of fatigue, abdominal distension, and jaundice. He has a known diagnosis of liver cirrhosis secondary to chronic hepatitis B infection. Recently, he has developed a palpable liver mass, and imaging studies confirm the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma. Which of the following parameters is not typically used in the prognosis of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serum ammonia

Explanation:

  • The prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with underlying liver cirrhosis is heavily influenced by liver function, which is often assessed using the Child-Pugh (CP) score.
  • Serum ammonia is typically associated with hepatic encephalopathy rather than being a direct measure used in the prognosis of HCC.
  • Therefore, it is not typically used in the prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic hepatitis B presents with increasing fatigue, weight loss, and right upper quadrant pain. Physical examination reveals jaundice and hepatomegaly. Imaging shows multiple lesions with a 4 cm mass in the right lobe and satellite nodules in the left lobe, along with portal vein thrombosis. His LFT shows elevated bilirubin and low albumin levels. The patient is diagnosed with HCC.

According to standard protocol, what is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Sorafenib
 

Explanation:

  • The patient has BCLC Stage C Hepatocellular carcinoma, characterized by the presence of vascular invasion, extrahepatic spread, or performance status of 1-2, the recommended treatment is systemic therapy with Sorafenib.

  • Sorafenib is used for both advanced and metastatic HCC as the preferred agent.

  • The treatment protocol adheres to the Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer (BCLC) guidelines for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)

Management of HCC

questions.text: A 24-year-old female from Southeast Asia presents with abdominal pain and a palpable liver mass. She has no history of hepatitis B or C infection, and no signs of cirrhosis. Imaging studies show a well-circumscribed, non-encapsulated tumor in the liver with a central stellate scar. Laboratory tests reveal normal alpha-fetoprotein levels but elevated neurotensin and B12 binding globulin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Fibrolamellar Variant of Hepatocellular Carcinoma

Explanation:
The Fibrolamellar Variant of Hepatocellular Carcinoma unlike other variants of HCC has the following characteristics:

  • Seen in young patients (<35 years) and incidence is Male=Female.
  • Well-circumscribed non-encapsulated tumor with a fibrous stroma and lamellar structure.
  • Not associated with hepatitis B, hepatitis C, or cirrhosis.
  • Presence of a central stellate scar on imaging.
  • Normal alpha-fetoprotein levels, along with elevated neurotensin and B12 binding globulin.
  • The investigation of choice is CECT and the treatment is resection of the tumor-infested hepatic region.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male presents with an asymptomatic palpable abdominal mass detected during a routine physical examination. The child has a history of low birth weight and no history of hepatitis B or C infection. Laboratory tests reveal elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels. Imaging studies show a large intra-abdominal mass. Biopsy confirms hepatoblastoma. Which of the following statements about hepatoblastoma is incorrect?

choices.text: Hepatoblastoma is the most common primary malignancy of the liver in children.
The most common route of spread for hepatoblastoma is lymphatic.
Hepatoblastoma is not associated with Hepatitis B or C infection.
The most characteristic laboratory abnormality is thrombocytosis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. The most common route of spread for hepatoblastoma is lymphatic.

Explanation:

  • The most common route of spread for hepatoblastoma is hematogenous, not lymphatic.

  • Hematogenous spread primarily involves the lungs as the most common site of metastasis.

 

Hepatoblastoma

Incidence

The most common primary malignancy of the liver in children

Age Group
  • Most patients are less than 18 months old
  • All patients are less than 3 years old

Associated with
  • Familial Adenomatous Polyposis
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome
  • Low Birth Weight (LBW)
 

Not associated with Hepatitis B or C, metabolic disorders, or cirrhosis

Clinical Presentation

Asymptomatic palpable intra-abdominal mass (hepatomegaly)

Laboratory Findings
  • Elevated alpha-fetoprotein level in 90% of patients
  • Thrombocytosis (Most characteristic)

Route of Spread; MC organ of metastasis

Hematogenous; Lungs

Diagnosis
  • Biopsy (Investigation of choice)
  • CECT (Radiological Investigation of choice)

Management
  • No metastasis- Resection
  • Metastasis- Resection + Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy (Vincristine, Cisplatin, 5-Fluorouracil)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic liver disease secondary to hepatitis C presents for evaluation due to worsening ascites, jaundice, and weight loss. He has been diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Imaging reveals a single liver lesion measuring 4 cm in diameter with no evidence of vascular invasion or extrahepatic spread. Laboratory studies show stable liver function tests and AFP levels below 100 ng/mL. Which of the following criteria is the most critical in determining his eligibility for liver transplantation?

choices.text: Tumor size less than or equal to 5 cm

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tumor size less than or equal to 5 cm

 

Explanation:

  • Milan Criteria is used to determine the eligibility of patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) for liver transplantation.
  • It helps to select patients who are most likely to benefit from the transplant, with a lower risk of cancer recurrence

Milan Criteria for Liver Transplantation

Criteria

Details

Tumor Size and Number
  • Single tumor ≤ 5 cm in diameter
  • Up to three tumors, each ≤ 3 cm in diameter

Absence of Vascular Invasion

No evidence of invasion of the major blood vessels by the tumor

No Extrahepatic Spread

No metastasis or spread of the tumor outside the liver

Hyperdense in arterial phase in Metastasis liver disease
Hyperdense in non-contrast CT in HCC
Hypodense in venous phase in Metastasis liver disease

Correct Answer: D) Hypodense in Venous phase in Metastasis liver disease
